<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_alloc_memory_:
```c
void *
MHD_connection_alloc_memory_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                              size_t size)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /* a short alias */
  struct MemoryPool *const pool = c->pool;     /* a short alias */
  size_t need_to_be_freed = 0; /**< The required amount of additional free memory */
  void *res;

  res = MHD_pool_try_alloc (pool,
                            size,
                            &need_to_be_freed);
  if (NULL != res)
    return res;

  if (MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace (pool,
                                     c->write_buffer,
                                     c->write_buffer_size))
  {
    if (c->write_buffer_size - c->write_buffer_append_offset >=
        need_to_be_freed)
    {
      char *buf;
      const size_t new_buf_size = c->write_buffer_size - need_to_be_freed;
      buf = MHD_pool_reallocate (pool,
                                 c->write_buffer,
                                 c->write_buffer_size,
                                 new_buf_size);
      mhd_assert (c->write_buffer == buf);
      mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_append_offset <= new_buf_size);
      mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_send_offset <= new_buf_size);
      c->write_buffer_size = new_buf_size;
      c->write_buffer = buf;
    }
    else
      return NULL;
  }
  else if (MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace (pool,
                                          c->read_buffer,
                                          c->read_buffer_size))
  {
    if (c->read_buffer_size - c->read_buffer_offset >= need_to_be_freed)
    {
      char *buf;
      const size_t new_buf_size = c->read_buffer_size - need_to_be_freed;
      buf = MHD_pool_reallocate (pool,
                                 c->read_buffer,
                                 c->read_buffer_size,
                                 new_buf_size);
      mhd_assert (c->read_buffer == buf);
      mhd_assert (c->read_buffer_offset <= new_buf_size);
      c->read_buffer_size = new_buf_size;
      c->read_buffer = buf;
    }
    else
      return NULL;
  }
  else
    return NULL;
  res = MHD_pool_allocate (pool, size, true);
  mhd_assert (NULL != res); /* It has been checked that pool has enough space */
  return res;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.

- No inline assembler or vendor-specific function qualifiers are used.
- All identifiers and constructs (const pointer declarations, size_t, function calls, standard C comments and Doxygen-style comments) are standard C, not documented compiler extensions.
- The literal true is a standard boolean macro from <stdbool.h> (C99 and later) rather than a compiler extension; mhd_assert is a macro call but not shown to use any compiler extension within this fragment.

Therefore there are no fragments that need further investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions should not be used).
